cleaned_text: Providence MCO Provider Directory For the most up-to-date provider listings, visit www.providence.org/php/mco .Providence MCO Provider Directory Table of Contents Provider panel membership is subject to change. To verify current participating providers, call your insurer or Providence MCO at 503-574-7640 or 800-947-4707. When scheduling appointments, be sure to identify yourself as participating in Providence MCO. iPortland Metro iiWe're Here for You iiiPlease note: While we make every effort to ensure the accuracy of this directory, provider status in this directory may change without notice. For more information or to confirm a provider's participation, please contact the MCO Service Team at 503-574-7640 or 1-800-947-4707, Monday through Friday between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. (Pacific time), or visit ProvidenceHealthPlans.com/mco .TTY users should call 711. If you have difficulty making an appointment , please call Providence MCO for assistance. Occasionally, physicians may temporarily limit the number of injured workers they are able to see or may be unable to take new patients if they currently have a full practice. Also, specialist physicians (e.g., orthopedic surgeons) may require a referral from a primary care or occupational medicine physician. The MCO staff is able to help you find a physician. For help finding a physician, please call us at 503-574-7640 or 1-800-947-4707. TTY users should call 711. Providence MCO is a state-certified workers' compensation managed care organization sponsored by Providence Health Plans. It is designed to provide coordinated high-quality medical care under Oregon workers' compensation laws. Because your employer or their workers' compensation insurer has contracted with Providence MCO, you now have access to the most experienced workers' compensation health care system in Oregon. Actual benefits will be determined by your employer or their workers' compensation insurer. Here's what Providence MCO does for you: Provides immediate access to the comprehensive system of hospitals, physicians, and other medical providers. Assures you of prompt diagnosis and expert treatment by qualified providers with expertise in treating work-related injuries. Works with your employer to give you sensible return-to-work options. Here's how Providence MCO works: If you experience a job-related illness or injury, you will be notified when your claim has been enrolled in the MCO. You must receive your medical care for that condition from a Providence MCO attending physician or your own primary care physician, authorized nurse practitioner, or chiropractor. Any specialty care, including physical therapy, must be provided by Providence MCO providers. If your treating provider does not participate in Providence MCO or does not meet the qualifications described below, you will need to change providers. What to do if you are injured on the job: Emergencies Dial 911 or seek treatment at the nearest emergency room. Non-emergencies You must seek treatment from a Providence MCO participating occupational medicine clinic, urgent or immediate care clinic, or Providence MCO participating physician or authorized nurse practitioner when your claim is enrolled in the MCO. You may be treated by your family physician, authorized nurse practitioner, or authorized chiropractor if this provider meets the following criteria: Your primary care physician must be an M.D. or D.O. specializing in family practice, general medicine, or internal medicine. If your primary care provider is a nurse practitioner, this nurse practitioner must be authorized by the Department of Consumer and Business Services to provide compensable medical services to injured workers. This physician or nurse practitioner must also have either a documented history of treating you before your injury or been selected as your primary care provider through your private health plan prior to your date of injury. An authorized nurse practitioner may treat you and determine your work status for 180 days from the date of the first nurse practitioner visit on the initial claim. An authorized nurse practitioner may not determine permanent impairment. Your non-MCO chiropractor must have a documented history of treating you before your injury and must be authorized by the Department of Consumer and Business Services to provide compensable medical services to injured workers. A non-MCO chiropractor may provide treatment for 18 visits or 60 days, whichever comes first, from the first visit on an initial claim and may determine work status for not more than 30 days. If you are treated by your primary care physician, authorized nurse practitioner, or authorized chiropractor and that medical provider is not a member of the Providence MCO panel, the provider must adhere to the terms and conditions of Providence MCO. If you live outside the MCO service area and there is a non-MCO provider who is closer to your home than an MCO provider, you may seek treatment with the non-MCO provider. This provider must adhere to the terms and conditions of Providence MCO . Referrals: Referrals to Providence MCO specialists are coordinated by your attending physician or authorized nurse practitioner. If there are fewer than three providers in one of these categories in your area, you may select a provider in that category who is not a Providence MCO panel provider: Optometrists Dentists Psychologists Acupuncturists Physical therapists Naturopathic physician Chiropractors Podiatrists These providers must adhere to the terms and conditions of Providence MCO when treating MCO-enrolled workers. Providence MCO naturopathic physicians and physician assistants may provide treatment without a referral for a limited time. Questions: If you have any questions, please call the Providence MCO Service Team at 503-574-7640 or 1-800-947-4707, Monday through Friday between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. (Pacific time).
